head.title: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00: Itinerary; Money Travels

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet
Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: The Way We Live Now: 10-15-00: Itinerary; Money Travels

abstract.p: Article traces routes of two one-dollar bills registered on Web site www.wheresgeorge.com; drawing (S)

block.p: More than 400,000 people have registered the serial numbers of five million bills, worth a total of more than $33 million, at the Web site www.wheresgeorge.com. Each bill is marked with the site's address -- O.K. so long as the bill is not rendered useless -- and then spent with the hope that subsequent possessors will visit the site and register the bill again, providing a fossil-like record (gaps included) of its movements.

One Dollar Bill Serial No. D0759 -- 2K, Series: 1995. Distributed by the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank. Aug. 18, 1999, Dayton, Ohio: ''Brand new bill. Stamped, circled serial number and wrote on top front.'' Sept. 25, 1999, Middletown, Ohio: ''Received this bill at Kwik N Kold Drive Thru in West Chester, Ohio.'' Nov. 24, 1999, Lexington, Ky.: ''At an auto parts place, condition of bill is fair. Wrinkled and a bit torn.'' Nov. 29, 1999, Richmond, Ky.: ''Received it as payment for merchandise. It is getting old!!'' Dec. 11, 1999, Henderson, Nev.: ''George came from Kentucky and landed in Las Vegas, where he will depart on 12/13/99.'' Dec. 30, 1999, Sun City, Ariz. May 2, 2000, Athens, Ohio: ''George is in good condition here in Bitterfeld (near Leipzig), Germany. Had to cheat the ZIP code, since it wouldn't accept one from Germany.'' July 24, 2000, Delhi, N.Y.

More than 400,000 people have registered the serial numbers of five million bills, worth a total of more than $33 million, at the Web site www.wheresgeorge.com. Each bill is marked with the site's address -- O.K. so long as the bill is not rendered useless -- and then spent with the hope that subsequent possessors will visit the site and register the bill again, providing a fossil-like record (gaps included) of its movements.

One Dollar Bill Serial No. D0759 -- 2K, Series: 1995. Distributed by the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank. Aug. 18, 1999, Dayton, Ohio: ''Brand new bill. Stamped, circled serial number and wrote on top front.'' Sept. 25, 1999, Middletown, Ohio: ''Received this bill at Kwik N Kold Drive Thru in West Chester, Ohio.'' Nov. 24, 1999, Lexington, Ky.: ''At an auto parts place, condition of bill is fair. Wrinkled and a bit torn.'' Nov. 29, 1999, Richmond, Ky.: ''Received it as payment for merchandise. It is getting old!!'' Dec. 11, 1999, Henderson, Nev.: ''George came from Kentucky and landed in Las Vegas, where he will depart on 12/13/99.'' Dec. 30, 1999, Sun City, Ariz. May 2, 2000, Athens, Ohio: ''George is in good condition here in Bitterfeld (near Leipzig), Germany. Had to cheat the ZIP code, since it wouldn't accept one from Germany.'' July 24, 2000, Delhi, N.Y.

One Dollar Bill Serial No. E4738 -- 0R, Series: 1995. Distributed by the Richmond, Va., Federal Reserve Bank. March 12, 2000, Lexington, Ky.: ''Got in change in Pike Co., Kentucky.'' July 6, 2000, Falmouth, Ky.: ''Found in Napa auto parts in Falmouth, Ky.'' Aug. 3, 2000, Georgetown, Ky.: ''This bill was given to me by a friend at Toyota Motor Mfg. Kentucky where we build the Camry, Avalon and Sienna. He gave to me because he doesn't own a computer.'' Sept. 20, 2000, Freelandville, Ind.: ''I got this bill from the cafeteria lunch line at our school at North Knox High.''
